Basic details: Sarah Green, a 40-year-old woman, comes to the clinic complaining of right calf pain.
Vitals:
BP: 120/75 mm Hg
Temp: 98.4°F (36.9°C)
RR: 18/minute
HR: 78/minute, regular
Physical presentation:
Sitting on the examination table with her right leg extended and slightly elevated.
Rubbing her right calf and wincing in pain when touched.
Exhibiting mild swelling in the right calf compared to the left.
If the examinee mentions a Doppler ultrasound, ask, “What is a Doppler ultrasound?”
Challenging question: “Could this be a blood clot? What should I do next?”
